Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Consulting Firms in the Nonprofit Sector

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The use of consultants is widespread in the U.S. nonprofit sector. Little is known, however, about the day-to-day reality of consulting firms? work in the nonprofit sector, or the influence of their recommendations on nonprofit practice. This study will illuminate how the work and interaction of consulting firms, clients, and funders define and implement core concepts in nonprofit work such as "social good" and "strategic." It will accomplish this by providing an analysis of consulting firms' processes, their relationships with client nonprofits, and links to funding organizations. Findings will contribute to policymaking concerning nonprofits and benefit philanthropic foundations and nonprofits themselves by revealing some of the consequences, intended and unintended, of consultant involvement in nonprofit work.

Situated as they are at the nexus of the nonprofit, for-profit, and philanthropic sectors, consulting firms working for nonprofits operate in a context in which goals, methods of measuring value, and accountability are unclear. This dissertation is motivated theoretically by the question of how organizations manage in the context of ambiguity and how their strategies to cope with ambiguity shape the nature of their work and the ideas they produce. To investigate these questions, this study will draw on 1) ethnographic data collected over 15 months at consulting firms located in Philadelphia, Chicago, and San Francisco (n=3 total firms), 2) more than 85 interviews with consultants and clients, and 3) a survey of foundations, which broker many consulting arrangements. The study will be among the first to investigate consulting firms? role in the generation and dissemination of assertions about nonprofit work, providing important insight about an understudied category of actors in the nonprofit sector.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nonprofit sector has long been considered a diverse and varied source of voluntaristic initiative, and a distinctive part of American society. However, scholars and professionals have suggested that amidst economic and societal pressure toward organizational efficiency and business-like practices, the nonprofit sector is at risk of losing its distinctive diversity. Consultants, used widely in the nonprofit sector, are thought to contribute to shifts in nonprofits toward becoming more instrumental and focused, and to the growing similarity of organizations across sectors. More broadly, in organizational sociology consultants are considered carriers of management ideas and fads into new settings and drivers of inter-organizational homogeneity in management practice. Drawing on ethnographic fieldwork in three strategy consulting firms that serve exclusively nonprofits, 180 interviews with consultants, client nonprofits, and philanthropic foundations, and a survey of foundations, this dissertation paints a more complex picture of consultants' role in the spread of new practices in the nonprofit sector. 

This dissertation shows that rather than driving similarity between nonprofits, consultants to nonprofits produced variation in the options for organizational structure and management strategy they created for clients, reproducing the heterogeneity of the contemporary nonprofit sector. These findings help explain scholars' observations that despite widespread changes in the nonprofit sector presumed to make the sector more uniform, the nonprofit sector remains decentralized and varied. More broadly, the case of consultants to nonprofits provides new insight on consultants' role in the diffusion of ideas and practices across organizational fields, helping explain why complete and rapid diffusion only rarely occurs.

Of interest to nonprofits and philanthropic foundations, this dissertation shows that consultants are not, for the most part, looking to siphon nonprofits' scarce resources or to deliver shallow or cookie-cutter work. On the contrary, most consultants to nonprofits care deeply about their clients and the nonprofit sector in general, and endeavor to do high-quality work that genuinely helps their clients, sometimes at the expense of their own firms' bottom lines. However, this study's results also provide watchwords for nonprofits and funders seeking consultants. When looking for a consultant, nonprofits should be aware of the assumptions about good nonprofit strategies consultants bring to the table, and these assumptions' unanticipated consequences. For example, consultants often defined "best practices" as common practices of similar organizations, which could limit innovation among nonprofits. Consultants also aligned nonprofits' plans with available funding, reinforcing funders' influence on nonprofits' work.

The study provides a description of the strategic planning process as undertaken by consulting firms working in the nonprofit sector. It provides consulting firms with a more comprehensive picture of the field and market in which they participate, an opportunity to reflect on their practices, and an understanding of salient market segments. It also supports prospective entrants to the field of consulting to nonprofits to understand the work and profession. Because nonprofits are a major vehicle for public resource distribution, understanding consulting firms' work is consequential in advancing policymaker knowledge about how funding and legitimacy are distributed in the nonprofit sector. Additionally, the study improves policymakers', philanthropic foundations', and nonprofits' understanding of the implications of hiring consultants, by supplying a description of the process of consulting work and illuminating the unintended consequences of consultant involvement in the nonprofit sector.
